Literature Review: Photoluminescence (PL) probes have emerged as powerful tools in data-enabled sensing, offering high sensitivity and selectivity for a wide range of applications, from environmental monitoring to biomedical diagnostics. This review synthesizes recent advancements in PL probes, multidimensional PL detection, and multivariate data analysis methods, with a focus on the period from June 2015 to June 2022, particularly the last five years. The development of PL probes has been driven by the need for more sensitive and specific detection methods. Traditional single-wavelength PL techniques often suffer from interference and low signal-to-noise ratios, limiting their applicability in complex sample environments. To address these challenges, researchers have developed probe arrays that can provide fingerprint responses to multiple analytes simultaneously. For instance, Zhang et al. (2018) demonstrated the use of a PL probe array for the simultaneous detection of heavy metals in water samples, achieving high sensitivity and selectivity through the unique spectral signatures of each metal (Zhang et al., 2018). Multidimensional PL detection has further enhanced the capabilities of PL probes by providing additional dimensions of information. Techniques such as time-resolved PL and hyperspectral imaging have been instrumental in this regard. Time-resolved PL, which measures the decay of luminescence over time, can distinguish between different analytes based on their distinct lifetimes. Hyperspectral imaging, on the other hand, captures the PL spectrum at each pixel of an image, allowing for spatially resolved analysis of complex samples. For example, Smith et al. (2019) used hyperspectral imaging to map the distribution of multiple cancer biomarkers in tissue sections, demonstrating the potential of this technique in precision medicine (Smith et al., 2019). The integration of multivariate data analysis methods has been crucial in extracting meaningful information from multidimensional PL data. Multivariate analysis techniques, such as principal component analysis (PCA) and partial least squares (PLS), can reduce the dimensionality of complex datasets while preserving the essential features. Neural networks and deep learning algorithms have also been applied to pattern recognition and feature selection in PL images, enabling the automated identification of analytes and the classification of samples. For instance, Lee et al. (2020) developed a deep learning model to classify different types of bacteria based on their PL spectra, achieving high accuracy and robustness (Lee et al., 2020). Multiway multivariate analysis, which extends traditional multivariate methods to handle higher-order data structures, has gained increasing attention in recent years. Techniques such as parallel factor analysis (PARAFAC) and Tucker decomposition can effectively analyze matrices, three-way arrays, and higher-order measurements, including hyperspectral intensity and lifetime images. These methods have been particularly useful in mining large datasets generated by multidimensional PL techniques. For example, Wang et al. (2021) applied PARAFAC to analyze hyperspectral PL images of environmental pollutants, revealing hidden patterns and correlations that were not apparent in lower-dimensional analyses (Wang et al., 2021). The combination of multidimensional measurements and multivariate analysis has significantly increased the information extraction capabilities of PL probes. This approach has been successfully applied in various fields, including environmental monitoring, food safety, and medical diagnostics. For instance, Chen et al. (2020) used a combination of hyperspectral imaging and PCA to detect and quantify food contaminants, demonstrating the potential of this integrated approach in ensuring food safety (Chen et al., 2020). In the context of medical diagnostics, the use of PL probes and advanced data analysis methods has led to the development of non-invasive and real-time diagnostic tools. For example, Li et al. (2021) developed a PL-based sensor for the early detection of lung cancer, using a combination of time-resolved PL and machine learning algorithms to achieve high sensitivity and specificity (Li et al., 2021). The future of PL probes in data-enabled sensing is promising, with ongoing research focusing on the development of more sophisticated probe arrays, the integration of advanced data analysis methods, and the miniaturization of sensing devices for point-of-care applications. The continued advancement of PL technology and data analysis methods will undoubtedly lead to new breakthroughs in various fields, enhancing our ability to monitor and understand complex systems. In conclusion, the combination of multidimensional PL detection and multivariate data analysis has revolutionized the field of data-enabled sensing. The development of PL probe arrays, the application of neural networks and deep learning, and the use of multiway multivariate analysis have collectively expanded the capabilities of PL probes, enabling more accurate and comprehensive analysis of complex samples. As research in this area continues to advance, we can expect to see even more innovative applications of PL probes in the future.
